author: Dimple Singh
title: PM Modi’s outreach to Vladimir Putin prevented ‘potential nuclear strike’ on Ukraine in 2022: Report
text:
PM Modi’s outreach to Vladimir Putin prevented ‘potential nuclear strike’ on Ukraine in 2022: Report
The role of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in advocating for peace and de-escalation proved crucial in preventing a "possible" nuclear conflict amidst the Russia-Ukraine crisis in 2022.
Washington: As tensions between Russia and Ukraine escalated in 2022, the United States took measures to prepare for the possibility of a nuclear strike by Moscow against Kyiv, CNN reported citing senior administration officials. According to the report, the Biden administration was deeply concerned that Russia might resort to using tactical or battlefield nuclear weapons.
In response, the US sought assistance from non-allied countries, including India, to dissuade Russia from such an attack. “One of the things we did was not only message them directly but strongly urge, press, and encourage other countries, to whom they might be more attentive, to do the same thing,” a senior administration official said.
PM Modi’s significant role in averting Russia-Ukraine crisis
India, under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, played a significant role in averting the crisis. PM Modi’s outreach and public statements condemning civilian killings and advocating for a peaceful resolution to the conflict were instrumental in international efforts.
“I think the fact that we know, India weighed in, China weighed in, others weighed in, may have had some effect on their thinking,” the senior administration official added.
During the SCO summit in Uzbekistan, PM Modi said to President Vladimir Putin that “this is not the era of war,” a statement that resonated globally and even made it to the G20 communique under India’s presidency.
What happened in 2022?
In late summer and fall 2022, as Russian forces faced setbacks in Ukraine, the National Security Council of the US convened meetings to develop contingency plans. Ukrainian advances on Russian-occupied territories raised concerns within the administration about potential triggers for a nuclear attack. Simultaneously, Russia allegedly circulated a “false flag story” about a Ukrainian dirty bomb, raising fears among US officials that it could be used as a pretext for a nuclear strike.
Despite these tensions, the US never detected intelligence indicating Russia was mobilising its nuclear forces for an attack. “We obviously placed a high priority on tracking and had some ability at least to track such movements of its nuclear forces,” a senior administration official said. “And at no point did we ever see any indications of the types of steps that we would’ve expected them to take if they were going down a path toward using nuclear weapons,” he added.

author: S.R.
title: Tumeur: un léger surrisque de méningiome pour les utilisatrices de plus de 45 ans de certaines pilules
text:
L'utilisation du lévonorgestrel n'est pas associée à une augmentation du risque de méningiome intracrânien. En revanche, une augmentation très faible du risque a été identifiée chez les femmes de plus de 45 ans, lors de l'utilisation prolongée et en cours de contraceptifs à base de désogestrel seul dosé à 75µg. L'utilisation prolongée de pilules contraceptives contenant du désogestrel présente un risque de méningiome pour les femmes de plus de 45 ans, toutefois "très faible" comparé aux autres progestatifs, selon une étude du groupement d'intérêt scientifique Epi-Phare présentée ce jeudi 19 décembre.
Cette étude montre "une augmentation très faible du risque pour les contraceptions à base de désogestrel seul, lors d'une utilisation prolongée et en cours chez les femmes de plus de 45 ans", selon un communiqué publié par plusieurs institutions sanitaires.
"Ce risque augmente avec la durée d'utilisation: il apparaît à partir de 5 ans d'utilisation et est multiplié par 2 au-delà de 7 ans d'exposition", précisent l'Agence nationale de sécurité du médicament, Epi-Phare et la Cnam.
Ces progestatifs sont commercialisés sous les noms d'Optimizette, Cérazette, Antigone, Lactinette, Elfasette, Clareal, Desopop et sous des versions génériques.
Le risque est jugé "très faible" Pour 67.000 femmes utilisatrices du désogestrel quelle que soit la durée d'exposition, l'étude observe un cas de méningiome opéré et "un cas pour 17.000 femmes exposées plus de 5 ans".
Le risque est jugé "très faible" comparé à celui observé pour six progestatifs déjà connus pour être à risque de méningiome" (Androcur, Lutéran, Lutényl, Colprone, Depo Provera et Surgestone qui n'est plus commercialisé en France).
Concrètement, il est par exemple de "100 fois inférieur" au risque lié au fait d'avoir pris du Lutéran pendant plus de 5 ans, a souligné Alain Weill, directeur adjoint d'Epi-Phare.
Aucun risque de méningiome n'a été observé en cas de durée d'utilisation de moins d'un an du désogestrel, sauf lors d'une utilisation antérieure d'autres progestatifs à risque. Et en cas d'arrêt depuis plus d'un an, le sur-risque de méningiome disparait.
Pas de hausse du risque avec le lévonorgestrel Plus rassurant encore, l'utilisation du lévonorgestrel, seul ou combiné à l'éthinylestradiol, "n'est pas associée à une augmentation du risque de méningiome intracrânien, quelles que soient les durées d'exposition", ajoute l'étude.
Cette étude est la première au niveau national à évaluer le risque de méningiome associé à la prise de contraceptifs oraux contenant du désogestrel et du lévonorgestrel, très utilisés en France avec plus de 3,6 millions de femmes concernées en janvier 2022.
Au total 8.391 femmes opérées d'un méningiome intracrânien entre 2020 et 2023 en France ont été incluses dans l'étude.
Sur le même sujet Une étude montre un risque augmenté de tumeurs lié à trois médicaments progestatifs En attendant d'annoncer, début 2025, des mesures permettant de réduire le risque de méningiome lié à l'utilisation du désogestrel, l'ANSM rappelle que "le désogestrel n'est pas un traitement hormonal de la ménopause" et "qu'après la ménopause, une contraception ne doit plus être prescrite".
S.R. avec AFP Les plus lus

title: Applied Digital (NASDAQ:APLD) Trading Up 3% - What's Next?
text:
Applied Digital (NASDAQ:APLD) Trading Up 3% - What's Next? Written by MarketBeat February 27, 2025 Share Link copied to clipboard. Applied Digital Co. ( NASDAQ:APLD - Get Free Report )'s stock price rose 3% during trading on Thursday . The company traded as high as $8.90 and last traded at $8.34. Approximately 13,410,298 shares traded hands during trading, a decline of 51% from the average daily volume of 27,230,598 shares. The stock had previously closed at $8.10. Get Applied Digital alerts: Sign Up Analysts Set New Price Targets Volatility in Applied Digital May Create an Entry Opportunity
Several analysts have commented on the company. Northland Securities raised their price objective on Applied Digital from $12.00 to $20.00 and gave the company an "outperform" rating in a report on Tuesday, February 4th. Compass Point began coverage on shares of Applied Digital in a research report on Tuesday, January 28th. They set a "buy" rating and a $10.00 price objective for the company. HC Wainwright lifted their target price on shares of Applied Digital from $10.00 to $12.00 and gave the company a "buy" rating in a research report on Wednesday, January 15th. Needham & Company LLC restated a "buy" rating and set a $11.00 price target on shares of Applied Digital in a research report on Monday. Finally, Cantor Fitzgerald lowered their price objective on Applied Digital from $15.00 to $14.00 and set an "overweight" rating on the stock in a report on Wednesday, January 15th. Nine equities research analysts have rated the stock with a buy rating, Based on data from MarketBeat, the company has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $12.11.
Check Out Our Latest Stock Report on Applied Digital Applied Digital Stock Performance MarketBeat Week in Review – 9/9 - 9/13
The stock has a market cap of $1.75 billion, a PE ratio of -4.53 and a beta of 4.78. The company has a quick ratio of 0.77, a current ratio of 0.77 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 1.22. The stock has a 50-day moving average of $8.41 and a 200 day moving average of $7.59.
Applied Digital ( NASDAQ:APLD - Get Free Report ) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Tuesday, January 14th. The company reported ($0.06) EPS for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of ($0.14) by $0.08. The business had revenue of $63.87 million during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $62.41 million. Applied Digital had a negative net margin of 127.86% and a negative return on equity of 117.67%. The business's revenue for the quarter was up 51.3% compared to the same quarter last year. During the same quarter last year, the firm posted ($0.05) earnings per share. Equities analysts predict that Applied Digital Co. will post -0.96 EPS for the current fiscal year. In other news, Director Richard N. Nottenburg sold 20,000 shares of the business's stock in a transaction dated Friday, January 17th. The stock was sold at an average price of $8.85, for a total value of $177,000.00. Following the completion of the sale, the director now directly owns 342,923 shares of the company's stock, valued at approximately $3,034,868.55. The trade was a 5.51 % decrease in their position. The transaction was disclosed in a document filed with the Securities & Exchange Commission, which is accessible through this link . 11.81% of the stock is owned by company insiders. Institutional Inflows and Outflows
Several institutional investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in APLD. Vanguard Group Inc. grew its position in shares of Applied Digital by 39.1% during the fourth quarter. Vanguard Group Inc. now owns 12,760,035 shares of the company's stock worth $97,487,000 after acquiring an additional 3,587,619 shares during the last quarter. Van ECK Associates Corp boosted its position in Applied Digital by 113.8% during the fourth quarter. Van ECK Associates Corp now owns 4,404,313 shares of the company's stock worth $33,649,000 after purchasing an additional 2,344,572 shares in the last quarter. Tidal Investments LLC grew its position in shares of Applied Digital by 14,635.7% in the fourth quarter. Tidal Investments LLC now owns 1,697,850 shares of the company's stock valued at $12,972,000 after purchasing an additional 1,686,328 shares during the last quarter. American Century Companies Inc. acquired a new position in shares of Applied Digital in the fourth quarter worth $12,843,000. Finally, Geode Capital Management LLC boosted its stake in shares of Applied Digital by 54.4% during the fourth quarter. Geode Capital Management LLC now owns 4,726,495 shares of the company's stock valued at $36,117,000 after acquiring an additional 1,665,335 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own 65.67% of the company's stock. Applied Digital Company Profile ( Get Free Report )
Applied Digital Corporation designs, develops, and operates datacenters in North America. Its datacenters provide digital infrastructure solutions to the high-performance computing industry. The company also provides artificial intelligence cloud services, high performance computing datacenter hosting, and crypto datacenter hosting services. author: Admin
title: Leading Online Business Consultant Lindsey Anderson to Be Featured on Netflix’s The Trust
text:
PORTLAND, OR – In the last 20 years, Lindsey Anderson, leading online business consultant, has become one of the most influential voices in the digital marketing space. To date, her work has been showcased in several major media publications such as Fox, NBC, CBS, Huffington Post, ABC, and others.
A business scaling expert, Lindsey offers multiple programs—including the Content That Converts 90-Day Transformation Program and the 1:1 Mastery Program—that help coaches, consultants and experts generate more high-quality leads and convert them into paying clients. She is also the driving force behind the Build and Monetize (BAM) Agency. Her agency goes beyond conventional advertising services, offering a comprehensive approach to elevate marketing and sales efforts.
The BAM Agency doesn’t just stop at running paid advertising campaigns; they actively support product launches and put their client’s entire marketing and sales strategy into overdrive. Their expertise extends beyond tactical aspects, encompassing years of business strategy, market positioning, and brain-based learning design.
Author of the best-selling book, The Click Technique, and host of The Millionaire Maker Show podcast, Lindsey has developed several online marketing strategies that have been instrumental in helping entrepreneurs scale their online businesses. Now, she will be putting her business acumen to the test when she appears on Netflix’s highly anticipated reality TV series, The Trust: A Game of Greed.
The upcoming show’s premise revolves around a group of 11 strangers who are competing to win the grand prize—a quarter of a million dollars. The catch? The contestants are awardedthe prize money at the beginning of the show in the form of a trust. The money belongs to them, and if they survive the entire season, each contestant will be able to claim an even share.
Unlike the average game show, the contestants’ fates are entirely dependent on each other, facing the dilemma of sharing the prize equally or strategically voting each other out. With the power to eliminate a contestant with just one vote, Lindsey and her peers grapple with the decision between relationships and money. The Trust is a riveting social experiment filled with drama, featuring betrayal, deception, paranoia, and greed as contestants fight to keep the big prize. The show challenges the conventional timeline of trust development, exploring whether trust can emerge among strangers when money is on the line.
To catch the first episode of The Trust: A Game of Greed when it airs on Netflix on January 10, 2024, click
here. To learn more about Lindsey and her business coaching services, visit her website today.

author: Jonathan Greco
title: OKC-based company Kimray announces 15% reduction in workforce
text: The Oklahoma City-based oil and gas control equipment manufacturer Kimray announced that it is reducing its workforce by 15 percent, impacting about 120 employees. >> Get the latest news stories of interest by clicking here.In a news release, Kimray officials said the reduction is to "narrow its focus on core business functions and strategic priorities." The reduction impacts all areas – including administration, sales, production and production support. "While there has been a softening in the oil and gas market, there is still a healthy demand for our product. After evaluating our long-term goals, we decided to focus more on Kimray's core business. This means reducing our staff and reorganizing our teams," Kimray CEO Thomas Hill III said in the news release. "This difficult decision is necessary for the long-term health of the company. We have employed thousands of people during our 75 years of business, and each one contributed to what Kimray is today. It is an honor to share life with so many wonderful people." >> Download the KOCO 5 AppKimray President Bob Cole added that the company will provide job placement and counseling services to help impacted employees find new jobs.
